newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australia govt sees hope on revenue measures.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australia govt sees hope on revenue measures.

text.p: Australian Treasurer Peter Costello said he did not expect the opposition Labor Party to block two key revenue measures from his Tuesday Budget.

"I think they will find it very hard, for example, to defeat the surcharge for high-income earners who don't take out private health insurance," Costello told a charted accountants briefing by video link.
"I think that they will probably not oppose the superannuation surcharge. I think that they would find it very hard to explain to low income earners any opposition to that," Costello said.
Costello's budget sought to make A$3.9 billion in savings in the year to June 1997 and A$7.2 billion in 1997/98.
Most of the measures are spending cuts, which require no parliamentary approval.
But revenue measures, such as those mentioned by Costello, must be passed by the upper house of parliament, the Senate, which the Liberal-National government does not control.
But the Labor opposition's failure to vote against any government bill will ensure its passage.
Costello's budget included a move to raise the Medicare levy by one percent for high income earners who do not have private health insurance.
The move is expected to generate A$60 million of revenue in 1998/99 and A$75 million the following year.

The superannuation surcharge is an extra 15 percent on the contributions of high income earners, a measure which is forecast to raise an extra A$480 million in 1997/98, A$470 million in 1998/99 and A$530 million in 1999/2000.
